THE PROEM.</br>Although great Queen, thou now in silence lye,</br>Yet thy loud Herauld Fame, doth to the sky</br>Thy wondrous worth proclaime, in every clime,</br>And so has vow'd, whilst there is world, or time;</br>So great's thy glory, and thine excellence,</br>The sound there raps every humane sence;</br>To say, thou were a fleshly Deity:</br>Thousands bring off'rings, (though out of date)</br>Thy world of honours to accumulate,</br>'Mongst hundred Hecatombs of roaring Verse,</br>Mine bleating stands before thy royall Herse:</br>Thou never didst, nor canst thou now disdaine,</br>T' accept the tribute of a loyall Braine;</br>Thy clemency did yerst esteeme as much</br>The acclamations of the poore, as rich;</br>Which makes me deeme, my rudeness is no wrong,</br>Though I resound thy greatnesse 'mongst the throng.

THE POEM.</br>No Phoenix Pen, nor Spencers Poetry,</br>No Speeds, nor Chamdens learned History;</br>Eliza's works, wars, praise, can e're compact,</br>The World's the Theatre where she did act;</br>No memories, nor volumes can containe,</br>The nine Olimp'ades of her happy reigne;</br>Who was so good, so just, so learn'd, so wise,</br>From all the Kings on earth she won the prize;</br>Nor say I more then duly is her due,</br>Millions will testifie that this is true;</br>She hath wip'd off th' aspersion of her Sex,</br>That women wisdome lack to play the Rex;</br>Spaines Monarch sa's not so; nor yet this Hoast,</br>She taught them better manners to their cost.</br>The Salique Law had not in force now been,</br>If France had ever hop'd for such a Queen;</br>But can you Doctors now this point dispute,</br>She's argument enough to make you mute;</br>Since first the Sun did run, his ne'r runn'd race,</br>And earth had twice a yeare, a new old face:</br>Since time was time, and man unmanly man,</br>Come shew me such a Phoenix if you can;</br>Was ever people better rul'd then hers?</br>Was ever Land more happy, freed from stirs?</br>Did ever wealth in England so abound?</br>Her Victories in forraigne Coasts resound?</br>Ships more invincible then Spaines, her foe</br>She ract, she sackt, she sunk his Armadoe;</br>Her stately Troops advanc'd to Lisbons wall,</br>Don Anthony in's right for to install;</br>She frankly help'd Franks (brave) distressed King,</br>The States united now her fame doe sing;</br>She their Protectrix was, they well doe know,</br>Unto our dread Virago, what they owe:</br>Her Nobles sacrific'd their noble blood,</br>Nor men, nor coyne she spar'd, to doe them good;</br>The rude untamed Irish she did quell,</br>And Tiron bound, before her picture fell.</br>Had ever Prince such counsellors as she?</br>Her selfe Minerva, caus'd them so to be;</br>Such Souldiers, and such Captaines never seen,</br>As were the subjects of our (Pallas) Queen:</br>Her Sea-men through all straights the world did round,</br>Terra incognitae might know her sound;</br>Her Drake came laded home with Spanish gold,</br>Her Essex took Cades, their Herculean hold:</br>But time would faile me, so my wit would to,</br>To tell of halfe she did, or she could doe;</br>Semiramis to her is but obscure,</br>More infamie then fame she did procure;</br>She plac'd her glory but on Babels walls,</br>Worlds wonder for a time, but yet it falls;</br>Feirce Tomris (Cirus Heads-man), Sythians Queen)</br>Had put her Harnesse off, had she but seen</br>Our Amazon i' th' Camp at Tilbery:</br>(Judging all valour, and all Majesty)</br>Within that Princesse to have residence,</br>And prostrate yeelded to her Excellence:</br>Dido first Foundresse of proud Carthage walls,</br>(Who living consummates her Funerals)</br>A great Eliza, but compar'd with ours,</br>How vanisheth her glory, wealth, and powers;</br>Proud profuse Cleopatra, whose wrong name,</br>Instead of glory prov'd her Countries shame:</br>Of her what worth in Story's to be seen,</br>But that she was a rich Aegyptian Queen;</br>Zenobia, potent Empresse of the East,</br>And of all these without compare the best;</br>(Whom none but great Aurelius could quell)</br>Yet for our Queen is no fit parallel:</br>She was a Phoenix Queen, so shall she be,</br>Her ashes not reviv'd more Phoenix she;</br>Her personall perfections, who would tell,</br>Must dip his Pen i' th' Heliconian Well;</br>Which I may not, my pride doth but aspire,</br>To read what others write, and then admire.</br>Now say, have women worth, or have they none?</br>Or had they some, but with our Queen ist gone?</br>Nay Masculines, you have thus tax'd us long,</br>But she though dead, well vindicates our wrong.</br>Let such, as say our sex is void of reason,</br>Know 'tis a slander now, but once was treason.</br>But happy England, which had such a Queen,</br>O happy, happy, had those dayes still been,</br>But happinesse, lies in a higher sphere,</br>Then wonder not, Eliza moves not here.</br>Full fraught with honour, riches, and with dayes:</br>She set, she set, like Titan in his rayes,</br>No more shall rise or set such glorious Sun,</br>Untill the heavens great revolution:</br>If then new things, their old form must retain,</br>Eliza shall rule Albian once again.

HER EPITAPH.</br>Here sleeps THE Queen, this is the royall bed</br>O' th' Damask Rose, sprung from the white and red,</br>Whose sweet perfum fills the all-filling aire,</br>This Rose is withered, once so lovely faire,</br>On neither tree did grow such Rose before,</br>The greater was our gain, our losse the more.

ANOTHER.</br>Here lies the pride of Queens, pattern of Kings,</br>So blaze at fame, here's feathers for thy wings,</br>Here lies the envy'd, yet unparalell'd Prince,</br>Whose living vertues speak (though dead long since)</br>If many worlds, as that fantastick framed,</br>In every one, be her great glory famed.</br>1643.</br>
